snippet.title: Why Writing a Pinch-to-Zoom Component Is Harder Than You Think
snippet.description:
Talk: Oli Legat - "Why Writing a Pinch-to-Zoom Component Is Harder Than You Think", React Summit US 2025

At first glance, building a pinch-to-zoom and pan component in React seems simple. After all, the browser‚Äôs gesture events are already there. But when you need realistic, design-friendly motion and the ability to zoom axes independently, the problem gets much trickier. In this talk, I‚Äôll share how we approached this challenge in our AG Charts React component: from the pitfalls of na√Øve implementations, to the realisation that pan and zoom are mathematically identical problems. You‚Äôll see how some pen & paper algebra unlocked a precise and intuitive gesture system where X and Y scales update independently‚Äîkept in sync with React state‚Äîdelivering smooth interactions beyond what you get in maps or images.

Watch the full talk with Q&A on GitNation website: https://gitnation.com/contents/why-writing-a-pinch-to-zoom-component-is-harder-than-you-think

Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings ‚Üí https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025

snippet.title: Plug and Play Design: Building Extendable React Applications
snippet.description:
Talk: Mateusz Jagodzi≈Ñski - "Plug and Play Design: Building Extendable React Applications", React Summit US 2025

In large React projects, feature toggles and conditional builds can quickly become messy. What if entire features could be added‚Äîor removed‚Äîjust by dropping a folder in or out of your project? In this talk, I‚Äôll show how a plugin architecture makes React applications more modular and easier to maintain, with practical code examples from our product.

Watch the full talk with Q&A on GitNation website: https://gitnation.com/contents/plug-and-play-design-building-extendable-react-applications

Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, QnA‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings ‚Üí https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025

snippet.title: Fixing React full-stack with zero-syntax type safety | by Tanner Linsley, creator of React Query
snippet.description:
Tired of "meta-framework fatigue"? Tanner Linsley, creator of React Query, reveals a ‚Äúclient-first" architecture that finally fixes full-stack React.

Experience end-to-end type safety with zero boilerplate. In this deep dive, Tanner demonstrates how TanStack Start leverages the Router to merge the speed of SPAs with the power of Server Functions. Learn how to build type-safe, isomorphic apps that scale.

üîó Follow the link to watch the full version of all the conference talks, Q&A‚Äôs with speakers and hands-on workshop recordings: https://gitnation.com/events/react-summit-us-2025utm_source=youtube&utm_medium=react-summit-US-talks-post-1-12-2025

‚è±Ô∏è Video Navigation:

01:20 - 04:36 | Zero-Syntax type safety: inference vs. annotations
04:36 - 06:00 | Client-first architecture: keeping the SPA mental model
06:00 - 07:45 | Why TanStack Router is 90% of the framework
07:45 - 09:39 | Live coding: CLI setup & project structure

snippet.title: React Summit US 2025 - The biggest React conference in the US - November 18 & 21, 2025
snippet.description:
The biggest React conference ‚Äì React Summit ‚Äì has come to the USA!

Network with fellow front-end and full-stack engineers, learn from industry experts, and promote your ideas all while experiencing the exciting vistas of Manhattan!

React Summit offers a hybrid format with both remote and in-person participation. The first day will be streamed from the New York venue including hybrid networking features and interactive entertainment; and the second day, as well as the numerous free workshops, will be streamed to the global audience online.

Take advantage of being a part of the React Summit US conference!
Stay tuned!
